The required angular resolution is based on the cavity size. The current information is
2MASS J16152023: 30AU (d=180pc). The cavity has not been resolved, cavity size from SED modelling. DoAr44: 30AU (d=125pc) 2MASS J16042165: 79AU (d=140pc) HD143006: the cavity has not been resolved, but ALMA-Cycle 0 hinted a cavity. The SED does not show signs of a cavity. PDS70: 80AU (d=140pc)
For the calculation of the desired angular resolution, we took the smallest cavity (2MASS J16152023). Observations with a beam of 0.3arc size will resolved the mm-cavity.

The requirement for the sensitivity is based on the continuum flux. We propose to spatially resolve the continuum emission at 100GHz (Band 3) of five transition disks, which has been observed before at different mm-wavelength. Our calculations for the requested RMS and resulting S/N are based on the mm-fluxes of previous observations. We aim to get a S/N of at least ~10 at the peak of the emission; and a S/N in the total continuum flux density of at least ~100. We calculate the flux at 100GHz as F~(100/nu)^alpha (where alpha is the integrated spectral index, and nu the frequency of previous observations). The values of alpha are obtained with the total flux from two optically thin wavelengths (e.g. Pinilla et al., 2014). The taken values are
alpha(2MASS J16152023-3255051)=3.22 (Pinilla et al., 2014) alpha(DoAr44)=2.77 (Pinilla et al., 2014) alpha(2MASS J16042165-2130284)=3.2 (Pinilla et al., 2014) alpha(HD 143006)=3.0 (we take an averaged value, not measured before) alpha(PDS70)=2.6 (Hashimoto et al., 2015)
The current available values at the peak of emission are:
2MASS J16152023 (650GHz)=123mJy/beam (beam 0.29 x0.20, ALMA-Cycle 0, van der Marel et al., 2015) DoAr 44 (345GHz)=16mJy/beam (0.25 x 0.19, ALMA-Cycle1, van Dishoeck et al., 2015) 2MASS J16042165(345GHz)=38mJy/beam (0.69x0.44, ALMA-Cycle 0, Zhang et al., 2014) HD 143006(340GHz) - no available published data PDS (230 GHz) =13.6 mJy/beam (0.97x0.48, SMA, Hashimoto et al., 2015).
For 2MASS J16152023, we require a sensitivity of 0.5mJy, for a S/N of at least ~10 for the expected peak of the emission at 100GHz (5.53mJy/beam, beam=0.3x0.3).
In parallel with continuum, we also want to observe CO isotopologues, we propose to obtain the abundant molecular gas lines 13CO, C18O (J=1-0), and H2CO, to have better constraints on the gas density distribution and therefore supplementary information of the gas to understand the origin of the pressure trap in these transition disks. For the spectral line observations, we use two different basebands with a bandwidth of 937.50MHz and a velocity resolution of 1.32km/s, which is enough to give some constraints on the amount of gas inside mm-cavities (e.g. Bruderer et al., 2014)

The correlator should be operated in Time Division mode, and in Dual Polarization setup to enhance sensitivity and signal-to-noise ratio. Using the 36 main array antennas, 7.5 GHz of bandwidth, we find a total time on source of ~25 mins

One of our main science goals is to compare ALMA and SPHERE maps with similar resolution (we have accepted SPHERE programs for the five disks with 0.04-0.06arc). We require a resolution ~3 times lower than SPHERE to be able to compare the radial distribution of micron- vs. mm-grains. If any asymmetric structure is observed with ALMA at this resolution, we can re-construct the SPHERE map with the ALMA beam, to compare the images.

We aim to obtain spectral index variations within a range of ~0.25, which enable to discern differences between grain growth in a particle trap (Figure 1). Since the spectral index is equal to alpha=(ln F6-ln F3)/(ln nu6 -ln nu3), with F being the flux at Band 6/3 and nu the frequency; this translates into a relative error tolerance in both Bands of ~0.10 i.e. a S/N of 10 for the peak of emission. Based on the previous observations, for 2MASS J16152023, the expected flux at the peak of emission is 10mJy/beam at 230 GHz (with beam size of 0.12 x 0.12) we calculate the desired sensitivity to be 1.0mJy.
In this case, we also ask for C18O, 13CO, and H2CO (Formaldehyde) with a velocity resolution similar than in Band 3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Transition disks (TD) are circumstellar disks with inner dust cavities and reveal an intermediate step of disk evolution. The recent gas and dust observations of TDs have given major support to particle trapping, most likely induced by planet-disk interactions. When a planet carves a gap in a disk, millimetre-sized particles are trapped at the pressure maximum in the outer gap edge, creating a ring-shaped mm dust continum. However, small grains (micron-sized particles) can move inwards through the gap, leading to a spatial segregation between small and large grains. The efficiency of such segregation mainly depends on the gas pressure profile (which mainly depends on the planet mass) and disk turbulence. Our program aims to observe at high angular resolution the distribution of mm-grains in five TDs, for which we have on-going observing programs in scattered light with SPHERE/VLT (that probe small grains) to resolve this spatial segregation at unprecedented resolution and test the origin and efficiency of trapping in TDs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
